Award.AwardTitle: Support for the Kitt Peak National Observatory (KPNO) Mayall 4-meter Telescope Facility
Award.AbstractNarration:
Kitt Peak National Observatory (KPNO) will operate and maintain the Mayall 4-m telescope located on Kitt Peak near Tucson, Arizona, during the FY16 - FY18 period to enable the following four key activities: (a) general scientific research by community scientists, prioritized by a community-based peer review process (approximately 240 nights); (b) execution of an imaging survey of the one-quarter of the night sky in near-infrared light (approximately 250 nights) to produce a high-value public dataset; (c) installation of the Dark Energy Spectroscopic Instrument (DESI); and (d) essential corrective and preventive technical maintenance as well as minor technology improvements necessary for the successful continued operation of the Mayall. This work will be accomplished within a collaborative agreement between NSF and the Department of Energy (DOE). KPNO is a unit of the National Optical Astronomy Observatory (NOAO), which is operated by the Association of Universities for Research in Astronomy (AURA), under cooperative agreement with the National Science Foundation (NSF).

Intellectual Merit: Research supported by this award will probe a broad range of modern astronomy and astrophysics issues including the nature of asteroids and dwarf planets in the Solar System, the formation and evolution of our own Milky Way galaxy as well as galaxies in the distant universe, and the distribution of dark matter and its influence on cosmic evolution. The wide-field near-infrared survey will be the foundation for creating a more accurate three-dimensional map of the Universe with DESI. In turn, that map will be used to distinguish between the competing effects of gravitation ("pull") and the still mysterious dark energy ("push") on the evolution of the Universe over the last 10 billion years. Calibrated images (as well as object catalogs from the near-infrared imaging survey) will be publicly available in a form that will allow creative reuse, multiplying their research value considerably.

Broader Impacts: Open access for enquiry-based research via peer review and open data for all will allow scientists and citizens to engage in the NOAO/KPNO research enterprise no matter who they are or where they work. The story of DESI, its technology as well as a new 3D map of the universe and what we learn from that, will be a central public engagement opportunity at the Kitt Peak Visitor Center, which receives more than 40,000 visitors per year. The DESI project brings together two federal agencies, five US federal research centers, two major private philanthropic organizations, and 16 US universities as well as highly specialized industrial partners. Many participants are early career scientists, some as early as undergraduate. In turn, the DESI project will transform the Mayall into one of the premier spectroscopic survey facilities in the world, leveraging more than 50 years of NSF investment in the Mayall and extending its scientific impact deep into the 21st century.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Mayall 4m telescope at the Kitt Peak National Observatory has a storied history. Since the early 1970s, it has been a premier ground-based instrument for optical and near-infrared astronomy, serving both the US and international community and available for the exploration of our Universe by any scientist with a good idea. Over its 50+ years in service, the Mayall telescope mapped distant galaxies, uncovered some of the best earliest evidence for dark matter in the Universe; investigated the detailed properties of stars, galaxies and the intervening gas; mapped the outer reaches of our Solar System, and carried out systematic surveys of the sky. 

The telescope is now transitioning to a new mission: to probe the nature of the mysterious dark energy that pervades the Universe and causes its inexorable expansion to accelerate. To enable this mission, it has been taken out of "open service" (where any astronomer could apply to use it) and equipped with a new world-leading instrument dedicated to this one project. This new instrument, the Dark Energy Spectroscopic Instrument (DESI), will undertake the greatest cosmic cartography experiment of all time: it will map the distances to more than 30 million galaxies and quasars, creating the most detailed map of the universe to date, and measuring, with extreme precision, the expansion history of the Universe over the last 10 billion years. The Mayall telescope was chosen for this mission for two reasons: its unique design makes it possible to observe a wide field of view, and its 1970-era "battleship" construction permits an immense and heavy instrument like DESI to be mounted on it with relative ease.

During the last five years (the period of this last NSF award), the telescope transitioned into this new mission. Astronomers first upgraded an existing camera (the Mosaic Camera) by equipping it with new, more sensitive devices and then used this camera to carry out an imaging survey of the sky. This survey was one of three surveys used to find targets for the DESI instrument?s mission. This imaging survey was completed in February 2018, and the data were calibrated and released publicly. The very same month, the telescope's nighttime operations were shut down to begin making modifications for the installation of DESI. The old top ring of the telescope was replaced with a new, stronger but lighter one that could allow for the weight of the new instrument while leaving the telescope balanced. The new instrument consists of many parts: six very large, new lenses, a focal plate carrying 5000 robot fiber positioners and sensitive CCD cameras to enable guiding and focusing, the accompanying electronics, about 50 meters of fiber cable, and 10 new, sensitive 3-arm spectrographs in a thermally controlled enclosure. The old Mayall control room on the dome floor was "retired," and a new more spacious control room was constructed and equipped with modern computers. The old telescope control system was also replaced, to allow full computer control and remote monitoring of the telescope and dome environments.

The DESI instrument has now been commissioned on the Mayall telescope and the system is ready for its new mission. Unfortunately, the COVID-19 pandemic has resulted in a temporary closure of the facility. However, when the Observatory is reopened and the Mayall is able to operate again, it will embark on its five-year mission to probe the detailed effects of dark energy on the motions of the galaxies and the expansion history of the universe. In the course of carrying out this mission, the Mayall and DESI will also measure the motions of around 10 million stars in our own Milky Way Galaxy, and, we hope, unveil new mysteries in the Universe.
